E como esta pesquisa ressalta esta evidente importância do Profissional de Enfermagem no tratamento dos Portadores da PC, se torna necessario ainda esclarecer os paradigmas, avancos ate entao realizados, e retrocessos da doenca, onde se realizou uma incansavel busca por Definicoes, Causas e Novidades no Tratamento da Paralisia Cerebral, a fim de que o enfermeiro atue de forma direta, coerente, evidente e necessaria no tratamento de seus Pacientes portadores da Paralisia Cerebral.

papers.title: Self-Injury as an Addictive Disorder
papers.abstract: Self-injury is a mental health–related behavior people engage in to feel pain because they feel numb, to experience physical pain to ease their psychological pain, or to experience an emotional release. Self-injury is more common in patients with other co-occurring anxiety or mood disorders. An addictive component to self-injury has been identified related to an increase in dopamine levels from the self-injury, which then disrupts normal dopamine production similar to substance use disorders. Instruments are available to help identify patients who self-injure along with questions that should be asked in the course of a mental health assessment and physical examination. Patients with self-injury should be treated for any underlying mental health disorder as well as for self-injury, which includes therapy strategies and medications. Nurses can play a vital role in identifying and treating this disorder, which carries risk factors including infection, accidental death, and a higher risk of suicide. [ Journal of Psychosocial Nursing and Mental Health Services, 58 (6), 13–16.]
papers.venue: Journal of Psychosocial Nursing and Mental Health Services

papers.title: Resisting Perceptions of Patient Untrustworthiness
papers.abstract: Abstract A beneficial therapeutic relationship between a patient and their clinician requires mutual trust. In order to effectively treat someone, a clinician has to trust the patient’s reports of their symptoms, relevant experiences, medical history, and so on. Many psychiatric symptoms do not have physical markers that can be verified by clinical testing, and thus psychiatrists have to accept more on trust than clinicians treating somatic illnesses. However, many psychiatric diagnoses are stereotypically associated with traits that indicate untrustworthiness (such as irrationality). In this chapter, I illustrate how psychiatric labels can signal stereotypes of untrustworthiness, and how this can have repercussions in clinical contexts. In particular, I show how perceptions of untrustworthiness cause epistemic injustices by unfairly reducing the perceived epistemic credibility of patients with psychiatric conditions.

papers.title: Validation of Stress Assessment Using Mobile Phone
papers.abstract: INTRODUCTIONStress is a universally experienced phenomenon. It represents a continuum which no single definition can encompass. Stress is considered as an external load or demand on a biological, social or psychological system (Lazarus, 1993). In general terms, stress is defined as the reaction of an organism to a change in its equilibrium. More commonly it is referred to, as, the tension one experiences in response to a threat (Lu et al., 2012). Cumulative stress in daily life impacts negatively on health and societal well-being. Stress being highly pervasive, is widely accepted as the leading cause of illness and diseases. This presents an inherent need to detect and monitor stress as a pre-requisite for eliminating stress and diseases caused due to stress. Yet, despite the scientific advances of modern times, stress continues to be measured only through a self declared questionnaire. Such a questionnaire has several limitations, including lack of portability to measure frequently.Physiologic responses to stress could be used as markers to quantify stress. As a rule, stress does not exist in the absence of stressors. Stressors are stimuli which evoke stress responses. They could be real or imagined, physical or psychological. Physical stressors pose a threat to a person's physical equilibrium such as an electric shock, prolonged exercise, or deprivation of sleep. A psychological stressor on the other hand could be an event that poses a threat to an individual's self-esteem, e.g., the pressure of solving a difficult mental task within a time limit (Lu et al., 2012). It has been recognized that all stressors, whether physical or psychological elicit the same physiological response. Among the various physiological responses to stress such as, changes in heart rate, blood pressure and body temperature, respiration, skin conductance etc., cortisol responses function as the chief biomarker of stress. Largest cortisol responses entailing longest time for recovery are found to occur as a result of acute psychological stressors. (Dickerson and Kenney, 2004) These stressors refer to tasks of motivated performance (public speaking and mental arithmetic) with both uncontrollable and social evaluative elements (i.e., task performance could be negatively judged by others) present in them.On the other hand, it has been widely acknowledged (Hecker, Stevens, von Bismarck and Williams, 1968, Scherer, 1986., Tolkmitt and Scherer, 1986) that human voice is influenced by stress. According to Chang, Fischer and Canny (2011) the human voice encodes a wealth of information about emotion, mood and mental state. Variations in speaking fundamental frequency, duration (Griffin and Williams, 1987) amplitude (Brenner and Shipp, 1987) etc., provide for changes in acoustic speech signal that are measured as correlates of stress. Alterations in acoustic signals could be an outcome of changes in respiration during stress. Rate of respiration increases during stress, as a result, sub glottal pressure increases during speech. This in turn increases fundamental frequency or pitch of voice. Increased rate of respiration decreases duration of speech between breaths. Dryness of mouth, activity of the muscles of the larynx, vibrating vocal cords affect the volume velocity through the glottis and thereby fundamental frequency which contribute to changes in speech production under stress. These facts tender human voice as a potential source for stress detection. Voice features that could be influenced by stress include loudness, fundamental frequency, jitter, zero-crossing rate, speech rate and high-energy frequency ratio (Rothkrantz, Wiggers, van Wees and van Vark, 2004). Utilizing these facts the stressMobile-a tool developed to assess stress, demonstrates the possibility of quantifying stress levels from voice features recorded in a mobile phone.The present investigation was conducted to validate stress assessment using stressMobile against salivary cortisol responses to psychologically induced stress task on a sample of university students. …

papers.title: Seven Steps to Fibromyalgia
papers.abstract: Objectives: Fibromyalgia [FMS] is characterized by spontaneous, wide spread, persistent, unexplained pain associated with tenderness [lowering of mechanical pain threshold] or allodynia [pain induced by nonnociceptive stimuli], with more than 10 out of 18 tender points [TePs]. A third criterion has been used, including several minor symptoms [fatigue, sleep disorders, stiff ness …] and probable FMS has been defined by two criteria out of three. These different definitions suggest that FMS is more than one disorder and that other criteria are probably needed.Conclusions: Our definition of probable or “in complete” FMS is based on the presence of spontaneous, wide spread, persistent pain, fatigue, and peripheral symptoms such as stiffness, of ten modulated by weather changes, stress, and exercise.Our definition of mechanical allodynia is based on pressure induced tendino-muscular pain [tenderness] usually associated with central symptoms such as sleep disorders [TePs syndrome].Fibromyalgia might then be defined by the association of two distinct conditions: incomplete FMS [spontaneous, diffuse pain, and fatigue], and tenderness [mechanical allodynia], both having been aggravated by physical deconditioning.

papers.title: [Pathophysiology of chronic pain. Classification of three subtypes of pain].
papers.abstract: Pain is a physiological sensation which aim is to alert for an upcoming danger that may threaten the individual. This system includes peripheral nociceptors that initiate the nociceptive message. Then, the information is conveyed to the brain through the spinothalamic tract that projects to the thalamus, insula, SII and other areas. In clinical situations, a dysfunction of this nociceptive system explains chronic pain that can be simply classified into 3 subtypes according to pathophysiological mechanisms. Case 1: the nociceptive system is functioning normally, and provides (appropriately) a pain message that informs the brain of a local inflammation, or cancer, or infection... This is the situation of chronic pain because of an excess of nociception. Case 2: there is a (past or present) lesion of the nervous system that induces a dysfunction in the pain system. This is the neuropathic pain. Case 3: between the two former cases, there is no evidence for a lesion in the nociceptive system, and there are no evidences for lesion at the peripheral level, but there are evidences of dysregulation(s). These are the cases of dysfunctional pain.

papers.title: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder: A Primer
papers.abstract: Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is classed as an anxiety disorder, listed in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders The DSM:V. Although considered a soldiers illness by many, all humans can develop the condition following any life-experience that involves exposure to death or the threat of death, serious physical injury, assault or sexual violence. Any such life-experience is considered traumatic whenever it is subjectively interpreted by the one experiencing the event as potentially life-threatening, extremely stressful, frightening, and outside of individual control.

papers.title: Adjustment Disorders
papers.abstract: The adjustment disorders (ADs) are one of the subthreshold disorders that has undergone a major evolution since the original Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of the American Psychiatric Association of 1952. The essential characteristics of AD is the presence of clinically significant emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable psychosocial stressor. Although the issue of boundaries in mental disorders is obviously profound and common, the issue of defining boundaries is especially problematic in the subthreshold diagnoses, for example AD, in which there are no symptom check lists, algorithms, or guidelines for the "quantification of clinical features." There are six AD subtypes: (1) depressed mood; (2) anxiety; (3) mixed anxiety and depressed mood; (4) disturbance of conduct; (5) mixed disturbance of emotions and conduct; and (6) unspecified. In addition there is an acute form (persistence of symptoms less than 6 months) and a chronic form (persistence of symptoms for more than 6 months) after the termination of the stressor or its consequences. Etiologically, the ADs are in the stress-related category of mental disorders and treatment often involves attempting to eliminate or mitigate the stressor(s), or to enhance coping with them. The AD diagnosis in children and youth has been related to more serious mental illness in adulthood. In adults the subthreshold disorder usually remits after the cessation of the putative stressor: Counseling and psychotherapy may be employed with more refractory patients.

papers.title: Borderline Personality Disorder: History of the Concept
papers.abstract: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) enjoys the dual distinction of being one of the most written about and talked about conditions in contemporary psychiatry, and of being the only condition among the nearly 400 in the current Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) (1) whose label provides no hint, no semantic handle, as to what sort of condition it is. One might argue that the seven eponymous syndromes of the DSM (Alzheimer's, Asperger's, Creutzfeld-Jakob's, Huntington's, Pick's, Rett's, and Gilles de la Tourette's) require a bit of study before their nature is clarified, but all the others either stem from common English roots (gambling, binge-eating, sleep disorder) or are decipherable from their Greek or Latin origins (trichotillomania: pathological pulling of hair; insomnia: absence of sleep, etc.). Borderline, when used adjectivally, suggests something that is in close proximity to something else. Indeed, in its first uses in psychiatry, borderline designated either (a) a condition that approximated another, already well-established disorder, or (b) a condition that occupied a region in between two rather indistinctly boundaried levels of mental functioning. As we shall see, the borderline of our current BPD is derived from both these usages.

papers.title: Symptomatology and Management of Acute Grief
papers.abstract: At first glance, acute grief would not seem to be a medical or psychiatric disorder in the strict sense of the word but rather a normal reaction to a distressing situation. However, the understanding of reactions to traumatic experiences whether or not they represent clear-cut neuroses has become of ever-increasing importance to the psychiatrist. Bereavement or the sudden cessation of social interaction seems to be of special interest because it is often cited among the alleged psychogenic factors in psychosomatic disorders. The enormous increase in grief reactions due to war casualties, furthermore, demands an evaluation of their probable effect on the mental and physical health of our population. The points to be made in this paper are as follows: i. Acute grief is a definite syndrome with psychological and somatic symptomatology. 2. This syndrome may appear immediately after a crisis; it may be delayed; it may be exaggerated or apparently al)sent. 3. In place of the typical syndrome there may appear distorted pictures, each of which represents one special aspect of the grief syndrome. 4. By appropriate techniques these distorted pictures can be successfully transformed into a normal grief reaction with resolution. Our observations comprise tot patients. Included are (i) psychoneurotic patients who lost a relative during the course of treatment, (2) relatives of patients who uied in the hospital, (3) bereaved disaster victims (Cocoanut Grove Fire) and their close relatives, ( ) relatives of members of the armed forces.

papers.title: Poststroke spasticity
papers.abstract: People who have strokes are subject to numerous potentially devastating sequelae, most often sensorimotor paresis, impairment of cognition and language, and other functional disabilities, including depression and dementia. Of these sequelae, spasticity occurring with motor dysfunction is a frequent finding that has to be evaluated in light of other diagnoses, such as central paresis, ataxia, pathologic stance or gait, and other coordination dysfunctions. Often, spasticity is not notably present in acute ischemic strokes but develops later on, and may then become a major obstacle for achieving independence in performance of activities of daily living (ADLs). Spasticity appearing after a stroke demonstrates quite convincingly that stroke is not a stable condition, but must be viewed instead as a dynamic condition that over time can precipitate additional impairments that were not necessarily noted or present in the acute phase. Poststroke spasticity (PSS) can indeed appear immediately after the ictus, but is most often seen later in the course of the illness. It then becomes a marker of changing or increasing sensorimotor malfunction and therefore requires repeated neurologic assessments. PSS can occur coupled with pain, be noted with decreased dexterity or positioning, or simply be associated with a gradual increase in sensorimotor paresis. When occurring late, PSS can induce changes in the entire health perception of the patient and caregiver. ADLs= : activities of daily living; PSS= : poststroke spasticity The authors thank Allergan, Inc., for supporting travel and meetings of an advisory group that met over the past 3 years to discuss the many issues of poststroke spasticity. It was found that no concise overview exists on this topic that reflects clinical as well as recent research findings. Therefore, this supplement was planned. Authors Michael Brainin, Bo Norrving, Brett Kissela, Jörg Wissel, David Burke, Geoffrey A. Donnan, Christopher Chen, Didier Leys, Alberto Esquenazi, Katharina S. Sunnerhagen, John Olver, Gerard E. Francisco, and Richard D. Zorowitz did not receive financial compensation or honoraria for contributing to this supplement. Authors Aubrey Manack and Patrick J. Gillard are employees of Allergan, Inc. The authors thank Allergan, Inc., for supporting the costs of production and for funding Imprint Publication Science, New York, NY, to provide editorial support in the preparation of this supplement.

papers.title: Депрессия, связанная со стрессом, в амбулаторной психиатрической практике
papers.abstract: The section Mood Disorders of ICD-10 (F32) doesn't include indications on the possibility of clinically outlined depressive episode (DE) associated with a stress. In the section Adjustment Disorders prolonged depressive reaction lasting more then two years is defi ned (F 43.21) as mild depression status. Results of this study clearly demonstrate the presence of clinically signifi cant depressive episodes with diff erent severity related to stress. It was revealed statistical reliable diff erentiation between the matter of a stress-factor and a type of depression. In response to dominating stresses with personal meaning of Th reat or Challenge for certain more frequently anxiety depression is formed and the stress factor with meaning of Loss suppose statistical reliable frequency of melancholicanxiety depression.

papers.title: On the Action of Alcohol
papers.abstract: Some writers have attempted to classify insanity into emotional, ideational, impulsive, and intellectual insaniity, according to whether the case showed mor-e prominently an emotional or ideational disturb- ance, etc.I say more prominently, for there never was yet known a case in which either of these artificial divisions of mental phenomena was alone affected ; thl-brain-functions were never so dissected, as it were, by disease.Again, some autlhors divide the cases of insanity according to their supposed causes.They speak of mania d potu as a distinct malady, while others fix upon a mere concom-nitant, and describe a puerperal mania, or phthisical mania, making a mere accident the godfather to the disease;

papers.title: Depression Associated with Physical Illness
papers.abstract: Depression often accompanies a medical condition. It may also happen that the presence of a chronic disease changes the social situation of a patient, who then responds to the change by developing depression. Among the various systemic diseases, endocrine diseases, viral infections, collagen disease, pancreatic cancer, vitamin B12 deficiency, and folic acid deficiency are particularly likely to cause depression. Drugs, including interferon, methyldopa, and steroids, may also be the cause of depression. The depression seen in organic brain disease (secondary depres- sion) includes depression in convalescence from disturbance of consciousness caused by head trauma or encephalitis, poststroke depression, and depression in Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, or other neurodegenerative diseases. The symptoms of depression associated with a medical condition are basically the same as those in endogenous depression, including depressed mood, sadness, diminished mental activity, and impatience. However, depression associated with chronic organic brain disorders is characterized by the predominant symptoms of diminished intellectual capacity, apathetic tendency, lability of mood, retardation in thinking and speech, and flat affect, whereas depressive mood, insomnia, anorexia, low self- esteem, obsessive-compulsive symptoms, and suicidal ideation are mild.

papers.title: Whiplash Injuries: An Interventional Approach
papers.abstract: Whiplash-associated disorders (WAD) occur when shifting of energy during a crash or collision, from acceleration-deceleration mechanism, is transferred to the neck region.WAD is characterized by excessive extension-flexion movements, and/or excessive side bending of the head and neck, beyond the normal and regular range of motion.Motor vehicle collisions remain the majority of trauma responsible for WAD.Nevertheless, other causes include contact sports injuries, falls, physical and domestic abuse, and other types of traumas.Clinical features and presentations are variable.In general, these includes neck pain, decreased range of motion at cervical spine, spasms and tightness, headaches, arm(s) numbness or pain, and other symptoms and signs depending on the extent of the insult.These range from fractures, joint dislocations, ligament tears, and even traumatic brain injuries/post-concussional syndrome, with its subsequent clinical sequalae.The trauma associated with WAD outcome can result in acute and chronic pain syndromes, functionality limitations and restrictions, psychological and psychosocial ramifications, financial crisis, unemployment, and certain cases, prolonged disability.This causes a significant economic burden on any country.

papers.title: The Need for Psycho-Spiritual History in Clinical Medicine
papers.abstract: In diseases of the body where the pathogenesis is presumed to be a disorder of structure and/or function of one or more of its components, the psychological aspect of the patient is side-lined and the spiritual aspect is out of consideration. In the presence of negative thoughts, the way a patient responds to a given treatment can be below expectations. Such negative thoughts can be recognized by probing into the patient’s mental attitude. Similar is the adverse effect when the patient feels a lack of genuine love and understanding in one’s social circle. Not recognising the presence of negativity in a patient’s psycho-spiritual history can lead to inappropriate or ineffective treatment. Inclusion of psycho-spiritual history in clinical medicine leads to opening up of a hidden aspect of the patient’s problem, which when tackled has significant therapeutic potential.
papers.venue: Clinical Medicine And Health Research Journal

papers.title: P-438 - Psychiatry without frontiers: one case of “zar syndrome”
papers.abstract: The concept of culture plays a major role in the understanding of mental disorders, as a human being is a social organism, modelled by the interaction with other people, and influenced by habits and objects in his/her own material culture, but above all endowed with a cultural heritage. Disorders occurring in defined cultural contexts are identified as "Culture bound Syndromes" (DSM IV-TR). In the present paper one case of "ZAR Syndromes" is reported. Male, aged 35, from Camerun. At the beginning tense, anxious, suspicious, confused, thoughts oriented by delirious ideation. He declares to be convinced of being possessed by "evil spirits", complains of hearing and sight hallucinations, speaks with altered voice. Feeble and changing mood. Owning several belts and amulets which should protect him against evil spirits, or reduce their power. Removing such objects, at the beginning, caused anger and aggressiveness, later on resignation and depression. The different adopted therapy protocols, based on benzodiazepines, antipsycotics, stabilizers, proved only partially effective, with a partial remission of the "affection" symptomatology and a persistence of the "psycotic" one. The patient, in his community, was considered as "possessed" since his adolescence, and was "educated" to worship "spirits". The patient was dismissed, after his own and his relatives' requests, so to allow him to go back home, where his relatives had him cured by a "healer". "Migrants" must be considered as subjects with own identity, worth to be respected, and avoiding any hegemonic temptations on behalf of western doctors.

papers.title: Social factors and health
papers.abstract: There is increased risk caused by social difficulties and/or childhood trauma for developing both general medical and mental health conditions, with overlap in similarity of magnitude of some increased risks, although intermediary mechanisms may differ. Social factors are the most important determinants of health status. Reducing social adversity and childhood trauma would improve the physical and mental health of the population. Life events and stresses/hassles are a more specific risk factor for mental health problems. Social factors are often inadequate to explain the nature and severity of people’s mental health problems without taking into account psychobiological factors. Given the greater effect of culture on how mental health conditions are expressed, there is some overlap between psychiatric and general medical diagnostic constructs rather than near total overlap. Mental health conditions do seem associated with greater stigma (some of this seems related to the categorical nature of diagnostic constructs) and also with greater use of coercion than for general medical conditions, but this also occurs for general medical conditions hence the conclusion of some overlap.

papers.title: 心理护理在“离退休综合征”老年患者护理中的体现
papers.abstract: ＂离退休综合征＂是指老年人在离退休后出现的适应性障碍。这种应激因素对心理、心身方面的干扰,使部分老年人在一个时期内难以适应现实生活,并且出现一些偏离常态的行为,甚至由此而引起其他疾病的发生或发作,严重地影响了健

papers.title: The development of a functional task-oriented measure of pain behaviour in chronic low back pain patients
papers.abstract: The cause of pain and disability in chronic low back pain (CLBP) is frequently difficult if not impossible to identify. Attempts to prove a causal relationship between identified pathological evidence, pain and disability are frequently disappointing. The suggestion that chronic low back pain would be better understood in terms of inappropriate responses to pain and that the concomitant disability was better understood as inappropriate illness behaviour was suggested by Fordyce [1]. One of the key aims of a behavioural approach to the management of disability due to CLBP is the reduction of inappropriate illness (pain) behaviour. Loeser and Fordyce [2] define pain behaviour as: 'any and all outputs of the individual that a reasonable observer would characterise as suggesting pain, such as (but not limited to) posture, facial expression, verbalising, lying down, taking medicines, seeking medical assistance and receiving compensation'.
papers.venue: Journal of Back and Musculoskeletal Rehabilitation

papers.title: Síndrome de sobreentrenamiento
papers.abstract: El sindrome de sobreentrenamiento (SSE) se define como la dificultad para mantener el desempeno, no justificado por otras causas o morbilidades y que persiste mas alla de 2 semanas a pesar de un adecuado periodo de reposo o recuperacion. El SSE es un estado de disminucion del rendimiento fisico combinado con alteraciones en el estado de animo. Las manifestaciones mas frecuentes son disminucion del rendimiento, sensacion de piernas pesadas, perdida de la fuerza, disminucion del estado de animo, apatia, disminucion de autoestima, inquietud, irritabilidad y trastornos del sueno. Multiples teorias se han planteado en el intento de explicar la genesis del SSE: la inadecuada periodizacion de las cargas de entrenamiento que podria generar cambios tanto fisiologicos como psicologicos en los deportistas; la realizacion de actividades extradeportivas de tipo laborales, estudiantiles, situacion personal y la constante y ascendente presion social; cambios de horario, viajes; disfunciones hormonales posiblemente inducidas por el ejercicio. Otras hipotesis planteadas hacen referencia a la presencia de alteraciones en el sistema inmunologico;  eficiencia en las concentraciones plasmaticas de algunos aminoacidos; deplecion del glucogeno muscular e insuficiente consumo de calorias. Debido a la complejidad del sindrome, la variabilidad y poca especificidad en la presentacion de los sintomas, el diagnostico de SSE se realiza por exclusion de otras patologias y requiere un alto indice de sospecha y vigilancia por parte de los profesionales encargados del proceso de entrenamiento y de los mismos deportistas. Sin embargo los intentos de realizar dicho diagnostico por medio de una prueba o grupo de pruebas de laboratorio han sido hasta el momento infructuosos. Entre estas las que mejor correlacion han demostrado son las mediciones de cortisol, testosterona en ayunas, el indice cortisol/testosterona, las concentraciones de adrenocorticotrofina y hormona del crecimiento. En cuanto a pruebas diagnosticas clinicas, se han disenado desde tiempo atras una serie de cuestionarios basados en los sintomas frecuentemente reportados de SSE: el cuestionario del perfil del estado de animo; la escala de percepcion esfuerzo; el cuestionario de la sociedad francesa de medicina del deporte (SMFS); el cuestionario de estado estres-recuperacion para atletas; la utilizacion de zonas individuales de funcionamiento optimo. Al igual que con las pruebas de laboratorio, las herramientas de tipo clinico han demostrado en mayor o menor grado su utilidad y el uso de las mismas depende del conocimiento, la validacion local y la disposicion de estudios previos que certifiquen su sensibilidad y especificidad dentro de las diferentes poblaciones. Para nuestro pais una buena herramienta seria el cuestionario SMFS para deteccion de manifestaciones tempranas de SSE, el cual se encuentra adaptado transculturalmente para nuestra poblacion y que fue con exito empleado por nuestro grupo de trabajo para la deteccion se SSE en deportistas de Antioquia en 2012. En casos en los que se han instaurado los sintomas y persisten por un periodo superior a 2 semanas, se hace necesario iniciar medidas que permitan recuperar al deportista, la mas efectiva es el reposo y la suspension de la actividad competitiva y el entrenamiento; aun hay discusion en la literatura sobre el tipo de reposo, el cual puede ser absoluto, con suspension de todo tipo de actividad deportiva, o relativo, manteniendo actividades de ejercicio reportadas como “suaves”. Otras medidas tanto preventivas como de tratamiento utiles en SSE, son la adecuada periodizacion del entrenamiento, las medidas de higiene del sueno, el control de factores estresantes ambientales y sociales, el adecuado aporte calorico ajustado a las necesidades del momento del entrenamiento y la terapia sicologica encaminada a aumentar la seguridad, la autoconfianza, la autodeterminacion y disminuir la ansiedad y las reacciones al fracaso. Lecturas recomendadas 1. Meeusen R, Duclos M, Foster C, Fry A, Gleeson M, Nieman D, et al. Prevention, diagnosis, and treatment of the overtraining syndrome: Joint consensus statement of the european college of sport science and the american college of sports medicine. Med Sci Sports Exerc 2013;45:186-205 2. Safarinejad MR, Azma K, Kolahi AA. The effects of intensive, long-term treadmill running on reproductive hormones, hypothalamus-pituitary-testis axis, and semen quality: A randomized controlled study. J Endocrinol 2009; 200:259-271 3. Hackney AC, Koltun KJ. The immune system and overtraining in athletes: Clinical implications. Acta Clin Croat 2012; 51:633-641 4. Jurimae J, Maestu J, Jurimae T, Mangus B, von Duvillard SP. Peripheral signals of energy homeostasis as possible markers of training stress in athletes: A review. Metabolism 2011;60:335-350

papers.title: Personality Disorders
papers.abstract: Personality is a term describing one's unique style or pattern of inner experience and outward behavior. Psychologists consider personality a long‐term, relatively consistent phenomenon, but healthy individuals are able to adapt their personalities to the demands of various situations. The difference for people with personality disorders is that their behaviors lack flexibility and tend toward extremes that impair their ability to interact well with others, causing problems in their work and family relationships. For example, they may be exceedingly sensitive, hostile, suspicious, deceitful, self‐absorbed, or impulsive, depending on the type of personality disorder they have. Mental health professionals consider personality disorders to be some of the most difficult problems to treat, especially given that most people with these disorders lack insight into the role they play in their own interpersonal problems. Thus, people with personality disorders continually replay their complex dynamics and relational struggles in both their daily lives and in the therapeutic relationship.

papers.title: Psychic Trauma and Traumatic Object Loss
papers.abstract: Psychoanalysis began with the concept of psychic trauma, which was subsequently not clearly differentiated from traumatic object loss or from unconscious conflict and fantasy. Psychic trauma is investigated in relation to unconscious conflict, with and without concurrent object loss. The syndromes of PTSD, uncomplicated by object loss, of traumatic bereavement, and of relatively nontraumatic bereavement, though often interwoven and inseparable, are all different. The significance of the loss, sociocultural factors, and group process influence individual responses to trauma and traumatic bereavement. There are specific neurobiological and psychological sequelae of traumatic experience. Clinical applications are noted.
papers.venue: Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association

papers.title: Procrastination, Perfectionism, and Other Work-Related Mental Problems: Prevalence, Types, Assessment, and Treatment—A Scoping Review
papers.abstract: Work-related mental problems can be defined as behaviors, emotions and cognitions that impede the successful completion of a task in a given time frame, i. e., the difficulty or inability to achieve important work-related goals. They are highly prevalent but have been neglected in psychology in general and as a target of psychotherapy in particular. Although work-related problems do not represent a mental disorder per se , they are associated with severe distress and high psychosocial costs. In this article, the prevalence of work-related problems, associated burden, diagnostic assessment and treatment are reviewed. So far, research has primarily focused on procrastination, i.e., the act of postponing or delaying tasks until the last minute or past the deadline. However, procrastination represents just one type of work-related problems among several others. Further forms of work-related problems are presented (e.g., perfectionism, or work-related problems in the context of specific personality types). The relation of work-related problems to specific mental disorders is discussed. Psychosocial interventions are the treatment of choice for work-related mental problems. However, response rates for the treatment of procrastination are limited, which calls for further research into which treatments work for whom. No evidence-based treatments are currently available for other types of work-related problems, with the exception of perfectionism, a personality trait that is also linked to problems in the field of work. Thus, there is a need to further improve the treatment of work-related problems including procrastination. For other types of work-related problems, effective treatments need to be developed and validated. They may be based on existing manualized treatments and extended by specific aspects or modules focusing on work-related problems.

papers.title: Pharmacologic Treatments for Fatigue Associated With Palliative Care
papers.abstract:
What is the best available evidence regarding pharmacologic treatments used to relieve nonspecific fatigue in people with advanced disease?
Type of Review
A systematic review of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) was conducted. Meta-analysis was performed when two or more studies of the same substance could be analyzed in a subpopulation of participants (i.e., with the same illness).
Relevance to Nursing
Fatigue is the most commonly reported symptom in individuals who have cancer and also is highly prevalent in populations with progressive life-threatening conditions. Fatigue presents a challenge for healthcare professionals because it can be nonspecific to treatment or illness, ongoing, subjective, and disabling to patients. In addition, the actual causes of fatigue are difficult to isolate, particularly in the person who is receiving palliative care because the symptom usually overlaps with concurrent disease-related problems such as malnutrition, sleep disturbances, pain, depression, asthenia, infections, and anemia. No consensus exists on the definition of fatigue or a standardized method of assessment. The working diagnosis used for the purpose of this review was “fatigue is a subjective feeling of tiredness, weakness or lack of energy” (Radbruch et al., 2008, p. 15).
In the context of palliative and advanced disease, fatigue can be viewed as an inevitable characteristic of the last phase of life. However, several pharmacologic treatments have been studied in an attempt to reduce the severity of the symptom and thereby improve the overall quality of life. Knowledge of effective medical treatments will be of particular interest to nurses who care for patients who frequently experience debilitating fatigue.

papers.title: Psychopharmacology in intellectual disabilities
papers.abstract: Little controversy surrounds the notion that persons with intellectual disabilities (ID) may engage in disruptive and challenging behaviours. One of the common referral queries to clinicians of people with ID – ‘Is this a mental illness or just a problem behaviour?’ – tends to stir up more discussion. At one extreme, attempts to understand maladaptive behaviours are merely descriptive and simply default to the ID itself. For example, aggression or self-injurious behaviour is said to be a product of the individual's cognitive disability and does not warrant a ‘diagnosis’. At the same time, the degree to which an individual is held accountable for his behaviour is also placed into consideration, as is the appropriateness of pharmacotherapy, depending on the answer to the referral question.

papers.title: 干休所离休干部“两高期”心理保健
papers.abstract: 生老病死生物界生命发展的必然规律，人类也是如此。人到老年各组织器官的功能逐渐减退，其心理意识也起着相应的变化，尤其在病魔缠身之际，希望健康长寿，又时时产生末日来临之感，而健康的含义不仅指身体健康，而且还要心理健康，身体健康与心理健康相互作用，互为因果。人是一个身心不可分割的整体，疾病给患者带来躯体的不适，同时也影响心理状态，而不良的心态又会加重躯体疾病。

papers.title: Clinical phenomena related to ‘problem patients’
papers.abstract: Somatisation is a tendency to express and communicate somatic distress and symptoms unaccounted for by pathological findings, to attribute them to physical illness and to seek medical help for them. Consequently, somatising patients are those who frequently complain of physical symptoms that either lack demonstrable organic bases or are judged to be grossly in excess of what one would expect on the grounds of objective medical findings (Lipowski, 1988). Such patients are commonly encountered in both primary and secondary care settings.

papers.title: Doctors Have Feelings Too
papers.abstract: The medical encounter, like all human interaction, is unavoidably emotion laden. Rather than viewing them as something to be overcome, the emotional responses of the physician can be analyzed for information about the patient or about the physician. The emotional states of patients arouse complementary reactions in the clinician that are diagnostic clues to important clinical syndromes such as depression or character disorders. Conversely, the physician can have idiosyncratic responses to patients that can lead to inappropriate diagnostic and therapeutic choices or to avoidance of particular problems or patients. Self-awareness is the key to utilizing these reactions to improve the patient-physician relationship.

papers.title: Somatization, sensitization, and functional dyspepsia
papers.abstract: Functional dysepsia (FD) is defined as persistent or recurrent pain or discomfort centered in the upper abdomen without evidence of organic disease likely to explain the symptoms. Visceral hypersensitivity, motor dysfunction, and impaired gastric accommodation are found in some patients with FD, and psychological factors like chronic stress, attention and perception bias are also likely to play a part in the symptom formation. There is considerable overlap of non-specific symptoms like fatigue, headache, abdominal discomfort, muscle pain, and sleep disturbance in patients with different functional disorders, in this article exemplified by FD, fibromyalgia, and chronic fatigue syndrome. This overlap of symptoms indicates a common underlying sensitization process, leading to somatization.

papers.title: Pseudodementia and Delirium in Depression: A Contribution to Psychosomatic Medicine
papers.abstract: Abstract: Presenting cases of depressional pseudodementia and delirium, we wish to point out the following points in this report. The patient in depression displays a state of pseudodementia when he is regarded as having senile dementia by the people around him. The depressed patient falls into delirium when he is embarrassed by an unexpected situation. In other words, the patient shows pseudodementia when he is continuously out of the world of daily meaning; he would fall into a disturbance of consciousness when he is suddenly put out of the world of meanings. This principle is applicable not only to depression but also to all mental diseases. In mental diseases, the symptoms themselves have some meaning for the patient. However, when the patient is put out of the world of ordinary meaning, mental disease presents the aspect of a somatic disease such as dementia or disturbance of consciousness.

papers.title: Migrânea: revisão de literatura
papers.abstract: Introdução: Cefaleia representa um problema de saúde pública, podendo ser primárias, quando são por si só a patologia ou secundárias quando são apenas um sintoma de uma outra patologia de base. Objetivos: Revisar as características e pontos principais da migrânea. Materiais e Métodos: revisão narrativa realizada em bases de dados digitais, livros e informações de organizações de referência mundial. Resultados: A migrânea é um tipo de cefaleia primária de alta prevalência, sendo mais comum em mulheres. Pode ser com ou sem aura – sintomas neurológicos focais que precedem a dor – ou crônica. Caracteriza-se por cefaleia pulsátil, unilateral, de intensidade de moderada a grave, associada a náusea, vomito, foto ou fonofobia e que se agrava com atividades físicas rotineiras. Deve ser diferenciada de outras cefaleias primarias e, quando na presença de sinais de alarme, também das secundárias, em especial se na terceira idade. Fatores como odores e luzes fortes, consumo de bebida alcoólica, certos alimentos, jejum prolongado, distúrbios do sono e ciclo menstrual podem desencadear uma crise. Seu tratamento pode ser farmacológico ou não, além de envolver medidas gerais; e pode ser sintomático ou profilático – mais indicado em casos mais graves ou refratários. Dentre os medicamentos utilizados durante as crises há os específicos (triptanos e derivados da ergotamina) e não específicos (analgésicos e anti-inflamatórios não esteroidais). Conclusão: Conclui-se que a migrânea deve ser reconhecida e diagnosticada correta e precocemente, objetivando uma terapêutica adequada e individualizada para que se alcance uma melhora na qualidade de vida do paciente.

papers.title: BACK INJURY AND DEPRESSION — A MEDICOLEGAL PROBLEM
papers.abstract: A possible cause for the persistence of symptoms following an injury to the back is put forward, together with a suggestion relating the psychiatric symptoms frequently seen in these cases to the initial injury. A depressive reaction as a primary result of the injury to the cervical spine is postulated, rather than as a result of failure of treatment or of persistent pain. The concept of litigation neurosis and the present state of medical evidence and attitudes toward a “functional overlay” are discussed in the light of this concept of depressive reaction after injury. This brings up a difference in evidence and attitude toward psychiatric disability in workers’ compensation law, since, as the Act at present differentiates between psychiatric conditions arising from the accident and those which result from pain and suffering occurring after a known physical disability, the present concept brings depression in an anxious individual into more direct relationship to the initial injury. The problems of anxiety in relation to litigation, and the effect of this on the efficiency of treatment of depression, anxiety and post-traumatic neurosis, are mentioned, and further work on this subject with particular reference to the immigrant population will be presented in a further paper. A follow-up study is needed to determine the mechanism of “cure” after settlement of insurance claims.

papers.title: Aralikli Patlayici Bozukluk Intermittent Explosive Disorder
papers.abstract: OZET Aralikli patlayici bozukluk ciddi saldirganlik ya da diger insanlarin malina za- rar verme ile sonuclanan ve yineleyen bicimde saldirganlik durtulerine karsi koyamama ataklari ile tanimlanan bir durtu kontrol bozuklugudur. Onceleri oldukca nadir bir bozukluk oldugu bildirilmisse de, artik ozellikle psikiyatrik orneklem gruplarinda olmak uzere daha once dusunuldugunden cok daha sik goruldugu kabul edilmektedir. Aralikli patlayici bozuklugun etyolojisinde cocukluk travmalari gibi psikososyal nedenlerin yani sira genetik faktorler ve serotonin, noradrenalin ve dopamin gibi cesitli norotransmitter sistemlerinde- ki duzensizlikler gibi biyolojik nedenlerinde rol oynadigi bildirilmektedir. Bu bozuklugun ayirici tanisinda alkol ve madde intoksikasyonu, antisosyal ve borderline kisilik bozukluklari, genel tibbi duruma bagli kisilik degisiklikleri ve davranim bozuklugu gibi agresyonun bir belirti olarak yer aldigi hastaliklar dusunulmelidir. Tedavisinde ise farmakolojik tedavi ile psikoterapotik surecin bir arada surdurulmesi onerilmektedir. Bu yazida aralikli patlayici bozukluk tanisinin tarihsel gelisimi, tani olcutleri, epidemiyolojisi, nedenleri ve tedavi yaklasimlari gozden gecirilmeye calisilmistir. Anahtar Sozcukler: durtu kontrol bozuklugu, aralikli patlayici bozukluk, agresyon ABSTRACT Intermittent explosive disorder is an impulse control disorder characterized by the occurrence of discrete episodes of failure to resist aggressive impulses that result in violent assault or destruction of property. Though the prevalence intermittent explosive disorder has been reported to be relatively rare in frontier studies on the field, it is now common opinion that intermittent explosive disorder is far more common than previously thought especially in clinical psychiatry settings. Etiological studies displayed the role of both psychosocial factors like childhood traumas and biological factors like

papers.title: Drinking, Alcohol Abuse, and Treatment in a Changing Cultural Environment
papers.abstract: This chapter views Navajo alcoholism within the framework of abusive drinking, and not from anyone conception of the disease of alcoholism. Abusive drinking is any use of alcoholic beverages that contributes to the development of a physical illness, a mental or emotional disorder, or the destabilization of an economic or social relationship that would not have otherwise been destabilized. This broad definition of alcohol abuse is employed because no single definition of alcoholism can adequately describe the variety of behaviors and clinical symptoms encountered when one studies or treats Navajos whose lives have been changed by frequent or poorly timed intoxication. When providing services to Navajos who suffer from alcohol abuse, this broad definition of 'alcohol abuse provides more insight into the manner in which intoxication contributes to the patient's maladaptation than any of the more strictly defined constructs, be they medical, psychological, or traditional

papers.title: CEREBRAL INJURIES DUE TO EXPLOSION WAVES— "CEREBRAL BLAST CONCUSSION"
papers.abstract: THE CONDITION known generically in World War II as "blast concussion,"<sup>1</sup>and discussed under synonymous titles by Fulton,<sup>2</sup>Pollock,<sup>3</sup>Fabing,<sup>4</sup>Aita and Kerman<sup>5</sup>and others, is presented here from the point of view of the organic basis of the syndrome. The first case to be described, which is one of the few of its type in which autopsy observations are on record, exemplifies the cardinal factors in this syndrome. These factors can be simplified as follows: One or more nearby explosions, causing no overt or external harm to the skull, nevertheless render the subject unconscious. After this, he has a retrograde amnesia for all but the flash of the explosion, and thereafter anterograde amnesia for a variable period. During this time he may have great motor unrest and normal or exaggerated responses to stimuli. On regaining consciousness, he has intense and intractable headache, which later

papers.title: 'The dwindles'. Failure to thrive in older patients.
papers.abstract: Geriatric failure to thrive has three elements: deterioration in the biological, psychological, and social domains; weight loss or undernutrition; and lack of any obvious explanation for the condition. It results from the combined effects of normal aging, malnutrition, and specific physical, social, or psychological precipitants (eg, chronic disease, dementia, medication, dysphagia, depression, social isolation). Failure to thrive can be managed with a commonsense approach by primary care physicians and healthcare providers such as social workers and dietitians; extensive referral is not necessary. The key to effective care is to identify all of the precipitants and intervene early to prevent progression.

papers.title: 《人体损伤程度鉴定标准》理解与适用--脑损伤
papers.abstract: 5.1颅脑、脊髓损伤 5.1.1a 植物生存状态（重伤一级）。 【理解与适用】 本条植物生存状态是指重度颅脑损伤导致大脑功能严重障碍，临床表现：（1）自身无意识，对外界无反应；（2）对视、听、触及有害刺激无精神行为反应；（3）无交流、表达能力；（4）睡眠-睁眼周期存在；（5）下丘脑、脑干机能尚保留（呼吸、心搏、脉搏及血压等）；（6）大、小便失禁；（7）颅神经及脊髓反射存在，但易变动，同时脑电图活动、脑干诱发电位存在。

papers.title: THE TREATMENT OF INSOMNIA.
papers.abstract: Insomnia is, of course, only a symptom but, like many other symptoms, it occasionally stands alone as representing some functional disturbance of which we have no other means of information. When we speak of the treatment of insomnia as such, we ought not to include the treatment of the pains or discomforts from various known sources which may keep the patient awake, or of many forms of insanity, of delirium tremens or other kinds of poisoning. This narrows our limits very much, but at the same time makes the problem more precise. The practitioner or writer, however, does not get rid of its difficulties by these exclusions, for many of the cases which present no other important symptoms, so that the patient has nothing to tell as to his bodily condition except that he can not sleep, are more difficult to manage successfully than one where we can put a

papers.title: 哥伦比亚大学Jeffrey A．Lieberman访谈：精神分裂症的防治
papers.abstract: 精神分裂症是一种原发性精神疾病，人群发病率为1％。精神分裂症的病因至今不明，其诊断仍旧是基于临床症状——表现出幻觉和妄想的“阳性”症状，表现出情感淡漠、回避社交以及无所爱好的“阴性”症状，而不是基于可辨认的分子异常或者诊断测试结果。疾病的进展是残酷的——从精神衰退到慢性精神病并最终完全失去行为能力。

papers.title: Wahnhafte Missidentifikationen - Klinik, Vorkommen und neuropsychologische Modelle -
papers.abstract: Delusional misidentifications include the Capgras delusion, Fregoli delusion, the delusion of subjective doubles and other less frequent symptoms. A common denominator of these unspecific psychopathological symptoms is the patients' denial of their identity or the convinction that their identity or the identity of relatives has been altered. These delusional symptoms occur in the context of somatic and mental diseases, most frequently in schizophrenia and dementia. According to neuropsychological and neuroanatomical studies delusional misidentifications are facilitated by lesions of the temporo-limbic system leading to an impairment in the affective recognition and reality control. Patients suffering from delusional misidentifications have a higher risk of aggressive behaviour which emphasises their clinical relevance.

papers.title: 和谐需要疼痛诊疗——贺“疼痛科”的诞生
papers.abstract: 疼痛是五大生命指征之一，机体无恙时，处于“休眠状态”，人们无从体验。当机体某组织发生损伤时，“疼痛”作为损伤的“警示”告诫／提示患者去看医生。而相关科医生则“循痛查病”，多数情况下可收“病除痛消”之效；故见之于临床各科的“急性疼痛”是“症状”这一立论，早已为医界所共识。倘这一损伤之发生与存在的时日较长（至终生），变成“慢性疼痛”时，此痛就失去其原有的“警示”作用，成为严重干扰生存质量的独立“疾病”。

papers.title: Phenomenological Psychopathology of Neurodiversity
papers.abstract: The term “neurodiversity” is commonly used to refer to intellectual disability or autism spectrum disorder, which are the neurodevelopmental disorders with the most severe impact on a person”s overall functioning along the life-span. Although a wide interpersonal variability, these conditions are associated with peculiarities in the subjective existential experience and in the psychological insight, with a particular reference to areas of emotionality, spirituality, practical skills, socialization, and psychic suffering. These peculiarities lead to a complex psycho-physical continuous vulnerability, including neurovegetative dystonia, lack of environmental mastery, low coping, difficulties in self-determination, repeated losses, and societal exclusion. Care provision should aim at improving quality of life, by enabling the “neurodiverse” (or “psycho-characterized”) person to pursue a self-development aimed at optimizing the relationship between importance and satisfaction in the most emic areas of life, such as being, belonging, and becoming.

papers.title: Suicidal behaviours, euthanasia and AIDS
papers.abstract: Introduction An increased risk of suicidal behaviours is considered almost a natural concomitant of many terminal diseases such as AIDS, malignant neoplasms, multiple sclerosis, and Huntington's disease [1]. Common reasons for suicidal ideation and acts in AIDS patients are social stigma, withdrawal of family support, diminished or lost occupational functioning, loss of personal autonomy, sense of hopelessness, and concern with the burden caused to significant others [2]. AIDS patients may also express the wish for passive suicide (i.e., stopping medical treatment), assisted suicide (planned together with other significant persons, sometimes with the physician) or euthanasia. These behaviours have been associated with a high prevalence of depressive syndromes reported in HIV- infected subjects [3], but have also been interpreted as a way of coping with the painful and unbearable social and emotional consequences of their disease and with the extreme physical and emotional suffering caused by the many debilitating conditions (i.e., wasting syndrome, opportunistic infections, cancer) that frequently occur in the late stages of HIV disease [4]. Many persons with AIDS consider ending their lives as a deliberate choice for a peaceful, rationally decided death before the inevitable, intractable physical and mental decline [5]. However, the debate in the area of HIV infection and end-of-life issues is limited to moral and legal aspects; the paucity of studies is evidence that the topic is still taboo or at least very much underestimated in the international AIDS research forum [6]. The general issues are regularly raised in the medico-legal press as international incidents emerge, such as the US Supreme Court decision not to issue a federal 'approval' for assisted suicide, but rather to delegate decision-making to individual states. This article reviews the empirical literature published on suicide and end-of-life issues in HIV/AIDS subjects. A Medline search has been performed (using the keywords HIV, AIDS, suicide, assisted suicide, and euthanasia) to locate relevant studies published between January 1985 and September 1997. The abstract books of the five most recent International Conferences on AIDS, and of related Satellite Symposia on Neuropsychiatric Aspects of AIDS, were used as additional reference sources. Definitions For the purpose of this review, 'suicide' is defined as a deliberate act to end one's life. A distinction is often made between 'rational' and 'irrational' suicide: the former refers to the act of a terminally or incurably ill person to hasten death; it would come at the end of an enduring illness rather than an impulsive decision, and would be taken by a competent adult in the absence of mental illness. Reasons to commit suicide in this case would be understandable by his/her peer group. On the other hand, 'irrational' suicide would connote the killing of one's self by a mentally disturbed person, often exposed to an overwhelming crisis; it would generally be an impulsive and violent act, carried out alone and in secret, without the support of a peer group. 'Physician-assisted suicide' (PAS) is the provision by a medical doctor of a causative agent (generally a medication) to a patient, at his/her request, with the intent that the patient will use the drug to commit suicide. 'Assisted suicide' is the provision of assistance to a person, at his/her request, to comply with his/her wish to end life. 'Euthanasia' is defined as an act or practice to cause a person's painless death, with his/her full informed consent. 'Medical euthanasia' requires, in addition, that there is a physician administering a treatment (usually medication) to hasten death (voluntary active euthanasia is another term to describe this action). 'Passive euthanasia' is characterised by the withholding or withdrawal of life-sustaining treatments (non-treatment decisions is another way to describe these actions). 'Non-voluntary euthanasia' is the act to intentionally cause a patient's death by administration of a treatment without the patient's full consent (the patient may be incompetent or may never have consented). 'Alleviation of pain with double effect' refers to the administration of drugs to relieve pain whose side-effects can cause respiratory depression/extreme sedation, resulting in the death of a patient. Finally, medical euthanasia, PAS, non-treatment decisions and alleviation of pain with double effect are generally included within the concept of 'medical decisions at the end of life'. Suicidal behaviours in AIDS patients Epidemiological studies Suicidal behaviours in AIDS patients have been investigated from a range of different perspectives: register studies, post-mortem examinations, evaluation of suicidal behaviour in cohorts of HIV-seropositive individuals, and seroprevalence surveys in persons hospitalized for suicide attempts [7]. Findings from register studies, in which population statistics on causes of death are matched with AIDS register data, are generally considered the most reliable and valid. However, in spite of the attention devoted to this research area in the last decade, the magnitude of the phenomenon has still to be clarified. The reported age-corrected relative risk (i.e., the ratio of the suicide rate of AIDS subjects to that of the general population in a defined age-group) can differ as much as fivefold (Table 1) [8–15].Table 1: . Register studies on suicidal behaviour in AIDS patients.The evidence of lower rates reported in more recent investigations has been interpreted as a possible consequence of better psychiatric management in HIV- infected subjects, lessened social stigma and wider availability of new antiretroviral drugs. The largely divergent results reported by Mancoske et al. [15], who estimated that the relative risk (not age-corrected) of suicide in persons with AIDS was 134.6 times higher than that of people without AIDS, can be explained on the basis of the inclusion criteria adopted: subjects with either an AIDS diagnosis recorded on death certificates or a diagnosis of 'opportunistic infections commonly seen in AIDS' (cytomegalovirus, Kaposi's sarcoma, Pneumocystis carinii pneumonia) [15]. Post-mortem studies (carried out on autopsies performed on violent or suspicious deaths, as stated by the coroner) represent a useful strategy to assess the prevalence of suicidal behaviours in HIV-seropositive persons not diagnosed as having AIDS. To date, one of the largest post-mortem studies that has ever been completed was carried out by Rajs and Fugelstad [16]. Out of a total 16 938 bodies examined during the period 1 July 1985 to 30 June 1990 at the Department of Forensic Medicine in Stockholm, Sweden, 85 showed positive results on HIV analysis. Twenty one (25%) of these 85 HIV-positive subjects had committed suicide; two of them had previously attempted suicide and nine were drug users. Similar results have been obtained by Barbieri et al. [17], who carried out a retrospective analysis of all judicial autopsies on violent or suspicious deaths performed in the Instituto Medico Legal in Sao Paulo, Brazil, between May 1985 and October 1988. They reported that 0.3% of all autopsies were HIV-seropositive. Of these 97 cases, 23.7% died as a result of suicide. No data on the suicide rate in seronegative subjects were presented. Even considering the estimate of those deaths from other causes occurring in HIV-seropositive subjects, these data seem to confirm that a significant proportion of all deaths in HIV-seropositive subjects is from suicide. Psychosocial risk factors Several studies have addressed the need to identify psychosocial factors that may increase the risk of suicidal behaviour in persons with HIV/AIDS [18–21]. It is well established that previous suicide attempts, current neuropsychiatric disorders (depressive syndromes and neuropsychological impairment), and chronic substance use are the strongest predictors of suicidal acts. Moreover, the importance of the following has been emphasised [18–21]: multiple psychosocial stressors, perceived social isolation, perception of self as a victim, reliance on denial as the main psychological defence mechanism, and perceived unavailable social support. Suicidal tendencies appear to be less frequent in women infected with HIV than in HIV-infected men, at least in a population of HIV-infected military personnel [22]. The adoption of coping strategies using more avoidance and less support-seeking was confirmed to be significantly related to lifetime suicidality in a sample of HIV-infected homosexual men [23]. In contrast, the perception of social support, sense of subjective integration, and use of behavioural escape-avoidance coping strategies were found to be unrelated to suicidal ideation in a sample of HIV- seropositive homosexual men caring for their HIV- infected partner [24]. Homosexual men and injecting drug users (IDU), who are at high risk of contracting HIV infection, have been reported to show high rates of attempted and successful suicide, irrespective of serostatus [25–28]. Atkinson et al. [29] examined 105 homosexual men for lifetime suicidality with a sociodemographically matched group of heterosexual men from the Epidemiological Catchment Area Study taken as a control group. The lifetime prevalence of major psychiatric disorders was much higher in the homosexual men than in the control group. Amongst homosexual men, however, no difference was found between HIV-seropositive and HIV-seronegative subjects. It appears that the increased risk of suicide in this group was related more to the higher prevalence of psychiatric syndromes than to HIV seropositivity. Lifetime prevalence of syndromal depression has been confirmed to be higher in HIV-seropositive homosexual men than in the general population by other research groups [18,30]. On the other hand, current depressive syndromes were not significantly different from those reported in the general population (6 versus 5%) according to Rabkin et al. [20], who surveyed a sample of long-term-surviving homosexual men with AIDS. Suicidal ideation was reported by 57% of the sample, but was related to the worsening of physical symptoms and to bereavement periods. Moreover, amongst those who attempted suicide, only 17% did it after AIDS diagnosis. A suicidal ideation less frequent in AIDS patients than in AIDS- related complex or asymptomatic subjects has been also documented by O'Dowd et al. [19], who proposed the following as possible explanations: adoption of denial as a coping strategy, refocusing of life goals in AIDS patients, and neuropsychological changes associated with central nervous system impairment. Gala et al. [31] explored the lifetime prevalence of psychiatric disorders in a sample of 218 HIV-infected subjects and 60 HIV- seronegative persons belonging to the same at-risk groups (homosexual men and IDU). The prevalence of attempted suicide was 22% in HIV-seropositive persons, 17% in HIV-seronegative persons, and only 0.2% in a control group drawn from the general population. Therefore, it can be argued that belonging to groups showing higher frequency of at-risk behaviours may be more important than actual serostatus in increasing the risk of suicide. The same applies to previous or concurrent psychiatric morbidity. In fact, no significant difference was found in the incidence of suicidal behaviours between patients attending a psychiatric outpatient clinic for HIV-related problems and a matched sample of patients attending a general psychiatry outpatient clinic [32]. For most AIDS patients, the first suicide attempt preceded the diagnosis of AIDS or HIV seropositivity. Methodological issues Some caution is needed, however, when considering the above epidemiological data [33]. Questions have been raised concerning the overestimation of suicidal phenomena due to the differential competing risk of non-suicidal deaths in AIDS subjects and in the general population, and the role of confounding factors, such as 'at-risk' lifestyles (known to be associated with an increased prevalence of psychiatric problems and suicidal behaviours). Furthermore, register studies have been carried out in subjects diagnosed as having AIDS, with only one exception, which obviously limits the generalizability of results to the much larger population of HIV-seropositive persons. On the other hand, persons undergoing HIV testing generally remain anonymous, making it impossible to relate a suicide act to HIV seropositivity (unless post-mortem testing is routinely performed in all violent or suspicious deaths). Finally, it should be considered that some suicide- equivalent deaths (e.g., such as those by drug overdoses or accidents) are often recorded as 'undetermined' and that many primary care physicians tend to consider death as the natural outcome of AIDS, whatever the final cause. This can lead to the underestimation of many 'rational' suicides (according to the above-mentioned definitions). A more general remark concerns the problem of definitions adopted to circumscribe the issue of suicide. This is a crucial matter of concern. In fact, errors in identifying suicides may vary to such an extent to hamper the validity of the studies reviewed. The lack of adequate registration of causes of death in mortality statistics can actually lessen the reliability of suicide statistics [34]. Euthanasia and assisted suicide in AIDS patients It has been argued that AIDS is the disease that makes the case for euthanasia [35]. Uncontrolled symptoms, psychological distress and human suffering are amongst the most compelling factors that lead HIV-infected patients to request PAS and euthanasia, and these practices are believed to be increasingly diffused amongst AIDS patients. Unfortunately, the epidemiological literature on assisted death and other medical decisions at the end of life in persons with AIDS is very limited. Prevalence of euthanasia/PAS: the empirical evidence The only epidemiological surveys currently available on the frequency of euthanasia and other medical decisions at the end of life have been carried out in The Netherlands, where these practices are no longer penalized, provided that a defined set of legal and medical guidelines is followed. The criteria, formulated by the Royal Dutch Medical Association [36], were included in regulations under the Burial Act and acquired formal legal status in 1990: The request for euthanasia must be free, voluntary, well considered and persistent; it is made by a mentally competent patient who has intolerable suffering (physical or mental) with no prospect of improvement; pain cannot be acceptably controlled with ordinary procedures; alternatives to euthanasia have been considered and extensively discussed with the patient; an independent judgement formulated by a second experienced physician has been obtained; a written report has been kept. It is not surprising that, as a consequence of depenalization, the number of reported cases of euthanasia increased dramatically from 19 in 1984 to 1318 in 1993 [37] giving researchers and decision-makers a unique opportunity to study and analyse these phenomena. Van der Wal and Onwuteaka-Philipsen [38] have recently published data concerning all cases of euthanasia reported in the province of North Holland from 1984 to 1993 (Table 2). Out of the total 1707 cases, 148 (9%) concerned patients with AIDS, compared with 1326 (78%) in patients with cancer. On the other hand, the rate of euthanasia out of all deaths due to AIDS was 13.41% (148 out of 1104) compared with 2.26% in cancer patients. The decision to perform euthanasia appeared to be associated with the extent to which intolerable and hopeless suffering was experienced, which clearly differs not only between patients but also between diseases.Table 2: . Epidemiology of euthanasia and assisted suicide in AIDS patients.It is of some interest that only slightly different results have been reported by Cooke et al. [39] from their small study to determine the extent to which Californian homosexual men in the terminal stage of AIDS receive medication intended to hasten death. Out of 140 persons with AIDS, 12.1% were administered a drug increase immediately prior to death with the deliberate intention of causing the patient's death. Somewhat contradictory figures have been reported by Laane [40,41] on euthanasia practices in AIDS patients in Amsterdam. In this town, according to the official death statistics, euthanasia and other medical decisions at the end of life in AIDS patients accounted for 21% of the overall incidence of euthanasia practices in 1991. The high rate was most likely due to the fact that about 55% of all AIDS patients in Holland reside in Amsterdam. The rate of euthanasia in AIDS patients was 21% of all AIDS deaths. In his survey amongst Amsterdam general practitioners, Laane found that the overall incidence of euthanasia/PAS amongst AIDS patients in Amsterdam was 26%. This figure was far greater than that found in cancer patients (7%). Moreover, other medical decisions at the end of life, such as non-treatment decisions and pain management treatments that may shorten life, were also more frequent in AIDS patients than in persons with other terminal illnesses. It is of some interest that the incidence of euthanasia/PAS amongst AIDS patients in hospitals and nursing homes is reported to be lower than in those living at home: 71.5% of AIDS-related euthanasia/PAS were performed at home, 26.5% in hospital and 2% in nursing homes. Loss of dignity, pain, unworthy dying and dependency were the most frequent reasons reported in euthanasia/PAS requests. A crucial question in the euthanasia/PAS debate concerns the decrease in survival time possibly associated with these practices. To address this problem, Bindels et al. [42] assessed the impact of euthanasia/PAS on survival time of persons with AIDS by comparing it with that of a group of AIDS patients who died from natural progression of the disease. The patients studied were 131 homosexual men enrolled in a cohort study in Amsterdam, diagnosed as having AIDS between 1985 and 1992. Results indicated that euthanasia had a very little impact on survival time: in the judgement of their physician, life was not shortened by more than 1 month in 72% of cases, and none of the patients would have lived more than an additional 3 months beyond the time of active intervention. Interestingly, a longer survival time from AIDS to death was found in the euthanasia group: authors argued that the continuing progression of HIV disease and the loss of quality of life might be a factor influencing patient's decision to avoid further suffering. Untreated pain syndromes Pain syndromes are highly frequent in subjects with AIDS, and up to 60% of hospitalized AIDS patients and as many as 80% of subjects in palliative care units report persistent pain experiences [43]. The severe and unrelenting suffering associated with AIDS was initially documented by Lebovits at al. [44], who reviewed the clinical records of 96 patients with AIDS: 43% of them had at least an analgesic prescription and 11% had a note regarding pain but not intervention. The inadequate treatment of pain in AIDS patients and the under-utilization of opioid analgesics has been reported by several authors [45,46]. Breitbart et al. [47] found that nearly 60% of 366 ambulatory AIDS patients presented persistent or frequent pain in the 2 weeks before the survey and that only 15% of them received adequate analgesic therapy. Women, less educated patients and IDU were those most likely to receive inadequate analgesia. Prevalence of euthanasia/PAS ideation and planning Available data on euthanasia/PAS ideation in HIV/AIDS patients are reported in Table 3. HIV- infected subjects may be no more likely than those with other terminal diseases to request PAS or euthanasia. This was found by Green [48] when assessing the proportion of people who considered asking assistance to end their lives in a cohort of 57 HIV-seropositive subjects. The proportion of persons who reported having ever or recently considered euthanasia was high (euthanasia ever considered, 28%; euthanasia considered in the last month, 10%) but comparable to that reported in a British cross-national study of friends and relatives of people dying from all causes of mortality [49]. However, significant differences were found when HIV-seropositive subjects were compared with a cohort of HIV-seronegative persons showing the same at-risk behaviours (euthanasia ever considered, 4%; P < 0.001; euthanasia considered in the last month, 1%; P < 0.05). Noticeably, lifetime and recent (last month) suicidal ideation was not significantly different amongst the two groups. The wish to die with dignity and to avoid losing personal autonomy were the main reasons to consider requesting help to hasten death.Table 3: . Prevalence of euthanasia/physician-assisted suicide (PAS) ideation and planning in HIV/AIDS patients.The relationships between AIDS, euthanasia planning, suicidal ideation and grief were investigated by van den Boom et al. [50], who interviewed 60 relatives (mainly partners) of 52 deceased AIDS patients in the period October 1988 to May 1990. In 22 out of 52 cases no medical decision at the end of life was made, and most of these patients had never discussed euthanasia. In 16 cases, death came after stopping or not starting a possible life-sustaining treatment, or as a consequence of the administration of increasing dosages of pain-relieving medication with the possible side-effect of shortening life. The life of 12 patients (25%) was terminated by means of a thanatic drug. With only one exception, all these patients had discussed and arranged for euthanasia in the early stages of the disease. No association was found between suicidal ideation and attempts, and euthanasia planning and arrangement. Authors gathered data on coping styles of the recruited subjects. Results showed that a functional and active behavioural coping style was more frequent in those who discussed the possibility of euthanasia more often and earlier, whereas depressive/avoidance coping was more common in patients who did not discuss the possibility of euthanasia or discussed it only in the terminal stages. Attitudes of HIV-seropositive persons towards assisted death have been surveyed in Belgium by Fleerackers et al. [51] in a sample of 315 HIV-seropositive subjects. Of the participants, 82% stated that physicians should be able to help terminate the life of an HIV-infected person at his/her explicit request if severe physical suffering is present, 50% in the case of psychological suffering, and 26% simply on demand. Of the sample, 67% felt that 'a physician should be able to administer a high dose of medication to terminate life quickly and painlessly.' Attitudes of persons living with HIV about assisted death have been also explored by Ogden [52], who reported findings regarding the unofficial phenomena of euthanasia/assisted suicide in British Columbia (Canada). His study documented 34 assisted deaths, often provided by lay individuals and friends of the patient, accounting for 2.7% of all AIDS deaths in British Columbia. Results showed that a majority (83%) of persons with HIV/AIDS considered euthanasia/assisted suicide as a possible choice. Plans for an assisted death had been prepared by 44%. Considering that assisting AIDS patients to die is a practice more common than generally believed, the author concluded with a plea for guidelines to regulate it. American HIV-infected patients clearly favour policies allowing PAS and euthanasia, according to Tindall et al. [53], who assessed attitudes of 53 AIDS and 52 HIV- seropositive white, homosexual patients; 95.2% of their sample expressed support for legalizing these practices. They stated that 'individuals with a life-threatening illness should have the option of euthanasia available.' These findings have been recently replicated in a survey carried out in 378 ambulatory HIV-infected subjects, of whom 90% were diagnosed as having AIDS [54]. Sixty-three per cent of the patients expressed a positive attitude towards the legalization of PAS and 55% acknowledged interest in PAS as a possible option for themselves. Supporters did not differ from non- supporters with regard to religious affiliation, health-related variables or subjective reports of intensity of pain. Independent predictors of personal interest in PAS were experience of the death of a friend or family member, suicidal ideation, race/ethnicity (Caucasian), less effective social support, and regular attendance of religious services. AIDS was amongst the diagnoses most frequently associated with an explicit request for PAS, as reported by Back et al. [55]. In their survey on patients' requests for PAS/euthanasia and physician responses in Washington State, the authors assembled a case series describing patient characteristics, physician perceptions of patient concerns, and physician responses to these requests. Cancer and AIDS accounted for 54% of all diagnoses made in the sample of 207 cases described (AIDS alone was reported in 13% of the sample); for patients whose prognosis was equal to or less than 6 months, cancer and AIDS accounted for 73% of the diagnoses. It must be noticed that, given the same life expectancy, AIDS patients requested assisted death more frequently than patients with heart disease.
